author: A_Brickset_user
title: GREAT!!
review: This set is one of my favorite sets of all time! its perfect for getting white castle walls, and a big Imperial Guard flag. Very cool design with the brig, the ladders and The Second floor. Good minifigs Including Admiral Woodhouse (I think thats his name) Awsome on its own. My favorite imperial base, scince I never got Imperial Trading post.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Hours of Fun!
review: I belive this was my first pirate set, but certainly my first imperial set.  I had hours of fun with this set, with the pirate and imperial soldiers, including the rare Governor minifig.  It should have had another rowboat, though, so then the soldiers could chase the pirate, cause they had swim after him :)

author: A_Brickset_user
title: GReaT sET yO
review:
this is a very nice set. i will start with the architecture.

the set has that same `Jamaican Port` feel to it, shared with Imperial Trading Post. it is a litttle unlikely that there would be part of a rock atoll there and no other half, but that's fine because it forms the "rowboat garage" and supports the side of the building with the cannon. the garage is very nice. the rowboat fits even if you stick the oars straight up by sticking them in those two holes right near the front of the boat. after arriving at the Outpost, soldiers could park their rowboat in the little garage and step right on to the outpost, where someone could give them some fresh ale (there are two small blue cups and a yellow\gold challace on a table that are visible on the box) and then the soldiers could go check on the pirate in the brig, which has a nice wooden doubledoor back door with a primitive lock system. the front of the brig can be opened easily by pushing down on the side of the bar system. there is also a small sand bar to the right of the jail (left if you're looking at it from behind) with a large palm tree. in front of the cell is a small dock with a trap door revealing treasure.however (this is the case in most Pirate sets so i didn't take points off) the treasure coins are in the water. when you lift the trap door, the coins will be resting on the blue baseplate. they would sink, but that's okay. Lego water is firm and stable. there is one other thing i wonder about the bottom floor. behind the table to the right is a small indent in the construction. instructions say to put a 1x2x1 yellow piece with a smooth top inside. does it represent a bag of grain or some kind of snack, or is it used to break part of the construction by pushing it back and up? if someone knows, please write a review about this set "(again, if you have already) and tell me. i would appreciate that.

the second floor is real nice. there are three "rooms". the one on the left is an outdoor "room" and has a cannon and a ladder to get up to the floor. the cannon does not fire, but the cannonballs are still nice (even though they're everywhere). there doesn't seem to be a way to get to the section within the walls, but who cares. maybe Legos can go through walls. the section in the middle is where Admiral Woodhouse studies maps and drinks fine wine. there is a little red roof coming out of the wall at the floor of this room, and Lego didn't design this roof thing very well. the roof pieces should be on the outside of the hinges, so that it looks more natural. of course, this would make it necessary to push the little lantern on a spear out farther (the lantern is "Totally Cool Beans") but it makes the roof look much better. the third section has nothing, really, just a place to stand and enjoy the view of the Caribbean Sea at sunrise, sunset, or whenever you like to enjoy the view of the Caribbean Sea (sorry, got a little carried away there).

above Woodhouse's study is a sentry post, also with a ladder (i like it that this set has ladders to everything, unlike the French set, Sabre Island. but that doesn't matter, because they are two different sets from two different eras, and maybe French people don't use ladders) and a big flag, possibly able to block the sentry's view. there is no fence in the back to keep the sentry from falling, but that's okay, why would he fall? stupid bums.

this set is great. buy it, because if you don't you don't know what your misssing. it comes with one pirate, two soldiers and Admiral Woodhouse. this set rocks, so get with it (a.k.a. buy it on ebay)

author: StormSworder
title: Great imperial outpost.
review: This is without doubt a fantasic set.  An imperial base/outpost, it is literaly packed with details.  There is a prison cell, a hidden area for treasure, an arched tunnel, a bar and a tower with battlements.  The palm tree and the general design of the building make it look very exotic, and the set includes a rare 'Governor' minifig.

author: hustla187
title: A Grand Old Set
review: This is a very cool set from 1995 from the Pirates theme. I like both the Pirates and Imperial sets and how they sometimes collide into one single set. I really like the fortress and the little space for the boat. A great set to own for Pirate fans.

author: albcheng123
title: A very Smart-Designed Fort
review:
With around 200 pieces, the "Imperial Outpost" is very smart-designed so that the fort can serve as many fuctions ---- cannon defence base, jail, tavern, dock, governor restplace & Sentry.

The governor is studying his treasure map while the soldiers are on patrol.  Of course, the officers can have a drink at the tavern for "Happy Hour".

The little pier allows small naval boats to have a park or to offload the cargos.

When the pirate ships appear, the rotatable cannon can warn them from coming closer (of course not the case when huge pirate ships approach  ^_^).

Never forget the small secret treasure hide under the grey brick terrain, a smart design that can prevent enemies from looting the gold coins.

Pros:
- Multi-functional imperial structure with around 200 bricks; very smart design!!
- Rare imperial guard minifigs (1 governor + 2 soldiers with Shakos)
- 1 Pirate minifig who allows lots of fun (Soldiers vs pirate's sneak attack)
- 2 ladders that allow the minifigs to climb up & down the building
- 1 Rotatable cannon to reinforce the defence
- A small Tavern for Happy hour
- A dock for small boats
- Some interesting special pieces such as the blue baseplate as ocean, red boat, palm tree, map, big imperial guard flag, & the cliff rock

Cons:
Can't think of any.  Probably more minifigs & bricks should offer more fun :)

If one can't afford the big forts such as "Eldorado Fortress (6276)" or "Imperial Trading Port (6277)", the "Imperial Outpost" should be a nice choice for constructing the "Imperial Fort".

author: MPH
title: Mixed feelings...
review:
This set appears to enjoy wide acclaim - and it's a nice set for sure - but compared to other 'classic' soldier sets (6267, 6265, 6276, 6277), I feel it is somewhat lacking. Let me explain...

 

Starting out with the ground floor, which is easily the best part. There is a dock for a small boat, a cosy tavern, some hidden treasure and a prison. In other words: fully packed with a variety of features, and quite some detail. The red roof and ingenious lantern are just icing on the cake.

 

However, things get progressively worse as we approach the higher levels. The first floor is about as dull as the ground floor is fun. Yes, there are a cannon and weapon rack, but it looks so bare! Where are those nice battlements found on most other soldier buildings? That stylish finishing touch? It just looks rushed...

 

The second floor is no better and shows a complete lack of inspiration. It seems to me that design focus has been on the ground floor, with other floors thrown in to beef up the size. They certainly do so, but they also affect the overall appearance in such a negative way for me, that I can't help to feel quite some letdown.

 

To end on a positive note: the minifig selection is excellent. I am more of a bluecoat fanatic, but having the admiral, two soldiers and a pirate all together in one affordable set is praiseworthy.

 

All in all, a 7 out of 10 for me; which I will bring down to three stars, since four would be too much.

author: SirSven7
title: Lego Steve's Review
review:
I loved this set, back in 1995 I received this set along with the Enchanted Island and the Renegade’s Runner for Christmas (All I ever asked for was Lego so I got a lot of it). As I got older I began to compare it to the Bluecoats version (Lagoon Lock Up 6267) sadly it’s not quite as good. The base of the set is the best part as it contains a dock for the boat a beautiful little kitchen space (with a table, two cups and a small oven), a trapdoor to hide loot (sadly going into water) and a jail.

But the set is let down by its flaws with the general layout, the jail door is at the back and cannot be reach without a boat (the jail floor itself is also in the water) and the middle and top floors contain nothing other than a cannon. I love the set but it’s not as well designed, we do receive a good minifig number in the form of another admiral for our Redcoats, two soldiers (a very large number for the Redcoat faction) and a pirate, which is a bonus, it’s a good basic set, but not faultless.

If you like this review click on the link to find it and all reviews of the pirate sets

http://legosteveblog.blogspot.com/2011/04/lego-pirate-wave-3-1994-1995.html

author: PeteM
title: Sizeable, Sparse Outpost
review:
Box/Instructions

The box was a fairly square affair, featuring a picture of the model superimposed in an ocean below golden red clouds, as though the set had badly photobombed a Turner sunset. The instructions are clear and fairly leisurely in pace – in fact it only has 5 steps fewer than the behemoth #6285 Black Seas Barracuda, which has over four times as many pieces and much more intricate construction. The back page features some decidedly eccentric alternate builds which are best ignored.

Parts

There is quite an assortment of parts for anyone wishing to play ‘pirate bingo’ – rowboat, check; palm tree, check; printed map and flag, check; assorted weaponry and treasure, check . . . sadly the only thing missing is a parrot. As could be expected with an Imperial soldier set, there is also the usual selection of basic bricks and arches in yellow and white, as well as a 16x32 blue baseplate. The white ‘castle’ wall panels included don’t feature the exposed red brick printing used in earlier similar sets, but as they are mostly covered up or hidden this is no great loss.

Minifigures

Included are a single pirate, two Imperial guards, and an Admiral. The Imperial faction are in the red uniform common to this era of pirate sets, with the guards sporting the classic smiley faces, as well as the epaulettes, backpack and hats that had been introduced with the theme in 1989. The Admiral fares slightly better, with a moustachioed face and what looks to be sideburns – printed faces were still fairly exciting, even then. He also has white (gloved) hands and gets a bicorne hat with fancy printing to show how important he is. The pirate has the common torso of striped vest covered with blue coat, and his face is printed with the usual eye patch, as well as an untidy fringe – the hallmark of a true rogue.

The build

The build is fairly standard brick on brick building, initially concentrating on the middle (tavern) and right (jail) sections. The boat dock on the left is formed simply from a rock piece as the outer ‘wall’, which then is connected to the main structure by arches supporting a deck at first floor level. There are no especially interesting or tricky bits of the build, though the lantern mounted on a spear is effective in it’s simplicity.

The completed model

The end result is surprisingly sizeable and spread across three levels. The ground floor has the highest level of detail (relatively), though it only uses minimal pieces to fill in necessary details and relies on a healthy imagination fill in the rest – most noticeably in the tavern section, which is simply a table with some mugs on it.

By contrast, the jail on the right is fully enclosed and I like the way the barred window is done, with the round 1x1 bricks that make up the frame interrupted by 1x1 plates with clips, which hold the bars half way up, resulting in a robust-looking construction. This is belayed only slightly by the fact that it can be easily rotated away (courtesy of a Technic pin as a hinge) in order for the pirate captive to make his escape onto the small landing stage. From here, he can lift a hinge plate up to reveal the concealed treasure and then leg it (oar it?) in the small rowing boat. I don’t remember being concerned that both the jail and the treasure compartment appeared to be seriously waterlogged, probably attributing it to dodgy builders...

The Admiral’s quarters take up the middle section of the first floor but are little bare – even a simple table and chair for him to sit at and sign death warrants and the like would have helped a bit, though from the illustration on the final step of the instructions, I assume he just uses the room to survey the seas, brandishing a goblet of unspecified drink while one of his minions mans the turntable-mounted cannon on the left hand side. The right hand section is a lovely palm-shaded veranda, complete with sea view and a weapons rack.

A ladder runs from the cannon emplacement up to the lookout stationed on the roof of the Admiral’s office, with only some low railings protecting the poor solider from plummeting off either side. An impressively large Imperial flag flies from the front battlement and tops off the set perfectly.

Overall opinion

Coming along six years after the theme began, this set proved that there was still a lot of mileage and interesting design possibilities to be explored in the Pirates sets. There’s a lot of play value in the set and it certainly packs a lot in – any number of stories can take place when you have a backdrop which includes a jail (with escape route), a tavern, a dock (with hidden treasure), an armed lookout with firing cannon and an Admiral’s base.

Thematically it fits right in with the rest of the range, constructed mostly of the yellow and white bricks synonymous with the Imperial faction and continues their habit of having random little bases scattered around the seas. The build isn’t fantastically exciting and I’m not convinced the increase in size over previous outpost-style sets necessarily adds anything – in fact the relative sparseness means that it doesn’t quite have the charm of some of the more compact Imperial outstations (6267 Lagoon Lockup still wins on that front). Having said that, the relatively impressive size and numerous play opportunities bump it up above average, and it would be a welcome addition to any Pirate set up.
